name: Directory
comment:
A reference to a directory (or folder) on the file system.

A Directory instance is an object holding a dart-io.Directory.path on which operations can be performed. The path to the directory can be dart-io.Directory.absolute or relative. You can get the parent directory using the getter dart-io.FileSystemEntity.parent, a property inherited from dart-io.FileSystemEntity.

In addition to being used as an instance to access the file system, Directory has a number of static properties, such as dart-io.Directory.systemTemp, which gets the system's temporary directory, and the getter and setter dart-io.Directory.current, which you can use to access or change the current directory.

Create a new Directory object with a pathname to access the specified directory on the file system from your program.

var myDir = new Directory('myDir');

Most methods in this class occur in synchronous and asynchronous pairs, for example, dart-io.Directory.create and dart-io.Directory.createSync. Unless you have a specific reason for using the synchronous version of a method, prefer the asynchronous version to avoid blocking your program.

Create a directory

The following code sample creates a directory using the dart-io.Directory.create method. By setting the recursive parameter to true, you can create the named directory and all its necessary parent directories, if they do not already exist.

import 'dart:io';

void main() {
  // Creates dir/ and dir/subdir/.
  new Directory('dir/subdir').create(recursive: true)
    // The created directory is returned as a Future.
    .then((Directory directory) {
      print(directory.path);
  });
}

List a directory

Use the dart-io.Directory.list or dart-io.Directory.listSync methods to get the files and directories contained by a directory. Set recursive to true to recursively list all subdirectories. Set followLinks to true to follow symbolic links. The list method returns a dart-async.Stream that provides FileSystemEntity objects. Use the listen callback function to process each object as it become available.

import 'dart:io';

void main() {
  // Get the system temp directory.
  var systemTempDir = Directory.systemTemp;

  // List directory contents, recursing into sub-directories,
  // but not following symbolic links.
  systemTempDir.list(recursive: true, followLinks: false)
    .listen((FileSystemEntity entity) {
      print(entity.path);
    });
}

The use of Futures

I/O operations can block a program for some period of time while it waits for the operation to complete. To avoid this, all methods involving I/O have an asynchronous variant which returns a dart-async.Future. This future completes when the I/O operation finishes. While the I/O operation is in progress, the Dart program is not blocked, and can perform other operations.

For example, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.exists method, which determines whether the directory exists, returns a boolean value using a Future. Use then to register a callback function, which is called when the value is ready.

import 'dart:io';

main() {
  final myDir = new Directory('dir');
  myDir.exists().then((isThere) {
    isThere ? print('exists') : print('non-existent');
  });
}

In addition to exists, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.stat, dart-io.Directory.rename, and other methods, return Futures.

Other resources

  • Dart by Example provides additional task-oriented code samples that show how to use various API from the Directory class and the related dart-io.File class.

  • I/O for Command-Line Apps a section from A Tour of the Dart Libraries covers files and directories.

  • Write Command-Line Apps, a tutorial about writing command-line apps, includes information about files and directories.

current=.name: current=
current=.comment:
Sets the current working directory of the Dart process including all running isolates. The new value set can be either a dart-io.Directory or a dart-core.String.

The new value is passed to the OS's system call unchanged, so a relative path passed as the new working directory will be resolved by the OS.

Note that setting the current working directory is a synchronous operation and that it changes the the working directory of all isolates.

Use this with care - especially when working with asynchronous operations and multiple isolates. Changing the working directory, while asynchronous operations are pending or when other isolates are working with the file system, can lead to unexpected results.

current.name: current
current.comment: Creates a directory object pointing to the current working directory.

systemTemp.name: systemTemp
systemTemp.comment:
Gets the system temp directory.

Gets the directory provided by the operating system for creating temporary files and directories in. The location of the system temp directory is platform-dependent, and may be set by an environment variable.

absolute.name: absolute
absolute.comment:
Returns a dart-io.Directory instance whose path is the absolute path to this.

The absolute path is computed by prefixing a relative path with the current working directory, and returning an absolute path unchanged.

constructors.comment: Creates a directory object. The path is either an absolute path, or it is a relative path which is interpreted relative to the directory in which the Dart VM was started.

fromUri.name: fromUri
fromUri.comment:
Create a Directory object from a URI.

If dart-io.Directory.Directory-fromUri.uri cannot reference a directory this throws dart-core.UnsupportedError.

create.name: create
create.comment:
Creates the directory with this name.

If dart-io.Directory.create.recursive is false, only the last directory in the path is created. If dart-io.Directory.create.recursive is true, all non-existing path components are created. If the directory already exists nothing is done.

Returns a Future<Directory> that completes with this directory once it has been created. If the directory cannot be created the future completes with an exception.

createSync.name: createSync
createSync.comment:
Synchronously creates the directory with this name.

If dart-io.Directory.createSync.recursive is false, only the last directory in the path is created. If dart-io.Directory.createSync.recursive is true, all non-existing path components are created. If the directory already exists nothing is done.

If the directory cannot be created an exception is thrown.

createTemp.name: createTemp
createTemp.comment:
Creates a temporary directory in this directory. Additional random characters are appended to dart-io.Directory.createTemp.prefix to produce a unique directory name. If dart-io.Directory.createTemp.prefix is missing or null, the empty string is used for dart-io.Directory.createTemp.prefix.

Returns a Future<Directory> that completes with the newly created temporary directory.

createTempSync.name: createTempSync
createTempSync.comment:
Synchronously creates a temporary directory in this directory. Additional random characters are appended to dart-io.Directory.createTempSync.prefix to produce a unique directory name. If dart-io.Directory.createTempSync.prefix is missing or null, the empty string is used for dart-io.Directory.createTempSync.prefix.

Returns the newly created temporary directory.

resolveSymbolicLinks.name: resolveSymbolicLinks
resolveSymbolicLinks.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments. dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks returns a Future<String>

dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks completes the returned Future with an FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

resolveSymbolicLinksSync.name: resolveSymbolicLinksSync
resolveSymbolicLinksSync.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments.

dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinksSync uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinksSync throws a FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

rename.name: rename
rename.comment:
Renames this directory. Returns a Future<Directory> that completes with a dart-io.Directory instance for the renamed directory.

If newPath identifies an existing directory, that directory is replaced. If newPath identifies an existing file, the operation fails and the future completes with an exception.

renameSync.name: renameSync
renameSync.comment:
Synchronously renames this directory. Returns a dart-io.Directory instance for the renamed directory.

If newPath identifies an existing directory, that directory is replaced. If newPath identifies an existing file the operation fails and an exception is thrown.

list.name: list
list.comment:
Lists the sub-directories and files of this dart-io.Directory. Optionally recurses into sub-directories.

If dart-io.Directory.list.followLinks is false, then any symbolic links found are reported as dart-io.Link objects, rather than as directories or files, and are not recursed into.

If dart-io.Directory.list.followLinks is true, then working links are reported as directories or files, depending on their type, and links to directories are recursed into. Broken links are reported as dart-io.Link objects. If a symbolic link makes a loop in the file system, then a recursive listing will not follow a link twice in the same recursive descent, but will report it as a dart-io.Link the second time it is seen.

The result is a stream of dart-io.FileSystemEntity objects for the directories, files, and links.

listSync.name: listSync
listSync.comment:
Lists the sub-directories and files of this dart-io.Directory. Optionally recurses into sub-directories.

If dart-io.Directory.listSync.followLinks is false, then any symbolic links found are reported as dart-io.Link objects, rather than as directories or files, and are not recursed into.

If dart-io.Directory.listSync.followLinks is true, then working links are reported as directories or files, depending on their type, and links to directories are recursed into. Broken links are reported as dart-io.Link objects. If a link makes a loop in the file system, then a recursive listing will not follow a link twice in the same recursive descent, but will report it as a dart-io.Link the second time it is seen.

Returns a dart-core.List containing dart-io.FileSystemEntity objects for the directories, files, and links.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a human readable string for this Directory instance.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.Directory.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

isAbsolute.name: isAbsolute
isAbsolute.comment:
Returns a dart-core.bool indicating whether this object's path is absolute.

On Windows, a path is absolute if it starts with \\ or a drive letter between a and z (upper or lower case) followed by :\ or :/. On non-Windows, a path is absolute if it starts with /.

absolute.name: absolute
absolute.comment:
Returns a dart-io.FileSystemEntity whose path is the absolute path to this. The type of the returned instance is the type of this.

The absolute path is computed by prefixing a relative path with the current working directory, and returning an absolute path unchanged.

parent.name: parent
parent.comment: The directory containing this. If this is a root directory, returns this.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.Directory.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.Directory.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.Directory.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.Directory.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.Directory.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.Directory.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

exists.name: exists
exists.comment:
Checks whether the file system entity with this path exists. Returns a Future<bool> that completes with the result.

Since FileSystemEntity is abstract, every FileSystemEntity object is actually an instance of one of the subclasses dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link. Calling dart-io.Directory.exists on an instance of one of these subclasses checks whether the object exists in the file system object exists and is of the correct type (file, directory, or link). To check whether a path points to an object on the file system, regardless of the object's type, use the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type static method.

existsSync.name: existsSync
existsSync.comment:
Synchronously checks whether the file system entity with this path exists.

Since FileSystemEntity is abstract, every FileSystemEntity object is actually an instance of one of the subclasses dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link. Calling dart-io.Directory.existsSync on an instance of one of these subclasses checks whether the object exists in the file system object exists and is of the correct type (file, directory, or link). To check whether a path points to an object on the file system, regardless of the object's type, use the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.typeSync static method.

rename.name: rename
rename.comment:
Renames this file system entity. Returns a Future<FileSystemEntity> that completes with a dart-io.FileSystemEntity instance for the renamed file system entity.

If dart-io.Directory.rename.newPath identifies an existing entity of the same type, that entity is replaced. If dart-io.Directory.rename.newPath identifies an existing entity of a different type, the operation fails and the future completes with an exception.

renameSync.name: renameSync
renameSync.comment:
Synchronously renames this file system entity. Returns a dart-io.FileSystemEntity instance for the renamed entity.

If dart-io.Directory.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing entity of the same type, that entity is replaced. If dart-io.Directory.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing entity of a different type, the operation fails and an exception is thrown.

resolveSymbolicLinks.name: resolveSymbolicLinks
resolveSymbolicLinks.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments. dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks returns a Future<String>

dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks completes the returned Future with an FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

resolveSymbolicLinksSync.name: resolveSymbolicLinksSync
resolveSymbolicLinksSync.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments.

dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinksSync uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinksSync throws a FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Directory.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

stat.name: stat
stat.comment:
Calls the operating system's stat() function on the dart-io.Directory.path of this dart-io.FileSystemEntity. Identical to FileStat.stat(this.path).

Returns a Future<FileStat> object containing the data returned by stat().

If the call fails, completes the future with a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

statSync.name: statSync
statSync.comment:
Synchronously calls the operating system's stat() function on the dart-io.Directory.path of this dart-io.FileSystemEntity. Identical to FileStat.statSync(this.path).

Returns a dart-io.FileStat object containing the data returned by stat().

If the call fails, returns a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

delete.name: delete
delete.comment:
Deletes this dart-io.FileSystemEntity.

If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is a directory, and if dart-io.Directory.delete.recursive is false, the directory must be empty. Otherwise, if dart-io.Directory.delete.recursive is true, the directory and all sub-directories and files in the directories are deleted. Links are not followed when deleting recursively. Only the link is deleted, not its target.

If dart-io.Directory.delete.recursive is true, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is deleted even if the type of the dart-io.FileSystemEntity doesn't match the content of the file system. This behavior allows dart-io.Directory.delete to be used to unconditionally delete any file system object.

Returns a Future<FileSystemEntity> that completes with this dart-io.FileSystemEntity when the deletion is done. If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity cannot be deleted, the future completes with an exception.

deleteSync.name: deleteSync
deleteSync.comment:
Synchronously deletes this dart-io.FileSystemEntity.

If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is a directory, and if dart-io.Directory.deleteSync.recursive is false, the directory must be empty. Otherwise, if dart-io.Directory.deleteSync.recursive is true, the directory and all sub-directories and files in the directories are deleted. Links are not followed when deleting recursively. Only the link is deleted, not its target.

If dart-io.Directory.deleteSync.recursive is true, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is deleted even if the type of the dart-io.FileSystemEntity doesn't match the content of the file system. This behavior allows dart-io.Directory.deleteSync to be used to unconditionally delete any file system object.

Throws an exception if the dart-io.FileSystemEntity cannot be deleted.

watch.name: watch
watch.comment:
Start watching the dart-io.FileSystemEntity for changes.

The implementation uses platform-dependent event-based APIs for receiving file-system notifications, thus behavior depends on the platform.

  • Windows: Uses ReadDirectoryChangesW. The implementation only supports watching directories. Recursive watching is supported.

  • Linux: Uses inotify. The implementation supports watching both files and directories. Recursive watching is not supported. Note: When watching files directly, delete events might not happen as expected.

  • Mac OS: Uses FSEvents. The implementation supports watching both files and directories. Recursive watching is supported.

The system will start listening for events once the returned dart-async.Stream is being listened to, not when the call to dart-io.Directory.watch is issued.

The returned value is an endless broadcast dart-async.Stream, that only stops when one of the following happends:

  • The dart-async.Stream is canceled, e.g. by calling cancel on the dart-async.StreamSubscription.

  • The dart-io.FileSystemEntity being watches, is deleted.

Use events to specify what events to listen for. The constants in dart-io.FileSystemEvent can be or'ed together to mix events. Default is dart-io.FileSystemEvent.ALL.
